content.description:
Many fictional characters struggle to find a place, either literal or metaphorical, where they can fit in. These characters feel disconnected from a particular community and may search for a place where they can belong or feel accepted.

Either from your own reading or from the list below, choose a work of fiction in which an individual or a group searches for a place to fit in. Then, in a well-written essay, analyze how that search contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole. Do not merely summarize the plot.
In your response you should do the following:

Respond to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation.

Provide evidence to support your line of reasoning.

Explain how the evidence supports your line of reasoning.

Use appropriate grammar and punctuation in communicating your argument.

Adventures of Huckleberry Finn

Americanah

An American Tragedy

Annie John

The Bluest Eye

The Bonesetter’s Daughter

Breath, Eyes, Memory

The Catcher in the Rye

Ceremony

The Color Purple

Disgraced

A Doll’s House

Dominicana

Frankenstein

The Good Conscience

The Great Gatsby

Gulliver’s Travels

Homegoing

A House for Mr. Biswas

How the García Girls Lost Their Accents

Interior Chinatown

Invisible Man

Jane Eyre

Madame Bovary

Native Son

The Poisonwood Bible

A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man

A Raisin in the Sun

The Red Badge of Courage

Silas Marner

Sing, Unburied, Sing

Snow Falling on Cedars

A Streetcar Named Desire

The Sun Also Rises

Tess of the d’Urbervilles

Their Eyes Were Watching God

There There

When the Emperor Was Divine

White Teeth

Wide Sargasso Sea

Wuthering Heights
content.question: In a well-written essay, analyze how that search contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Describe how textual details reveal nuances and complexities in characters' relationships with one another.
